events.event_description: U.S. natural gas consumption reached an all-time high of 89.1 billion cubic feet per day in 2023, marking the highest annual consumption on record.
events.citation: In 2023, 89.1 billion cubic feet per day (Bcf/d) of natural gas was consumed in the United States, the most on record.

events.event_description: Natural gas consumption in the electric power sector set monthly records in July and August 2023, reaching 47.5 Bcf/d and 47.2 Bcf/d respectively, despite cooler temperatures than 2022.
events.citation: Natural gas consumption in the electric power sector, which typically increases in July and August to meet air-conditioning demand, increased by 6% in July and August 2023 compared with those months in 2022, setting monthly records of 47.5 Bcf/d in July and 47.2 Bcf/d in August.

events.event_description: The highest monthly natural gas consumption in 2023 occurred in January at 106.6 Bcf/d, though this was 8% lower than January 2022 due to warmer temperatures.
events.citation: The most natural gas consumed in the United States in any month of 2023 occurred in January at 106.6 Bcf/d, but consumption was 8% less than in January 2022. Warmer-than-average temperatures reduced natural gas consumption in the residential and commercial sectors to meet space-heating demand.

events.event_description: The electric power sector saw the largest increase in natural gas consumption among all economic sectors in 2023, rising 7% to reach a record 35.4 Bcf/d, while residential consumption fell 10% and commercial fell 6%.
events.citation: In 2023, natural gas consumption fell 10% in the residential sector to 12.3 Bcf/d compared with 2022 and 6%, or 0.5 Bcf/d, in the commercial sector. The amount of natural gas consumed in the industrial sector remained unchanged, averaging 23.4 Bcf/d. The largest increase in natural gas consumption by a U.S. economic sector in 2023 came in the electric power sector, which increased 7% (2.2 Bcf/d) from 33.2 Bcf/d in 2022 to a record of 35.4 Bcf/d.
